summary: David Marwell was involved with the JFK Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB). He is mentioned in the context of the CIA's interactions with the ARRB regarding the review and release of JFK assassination records. One document specifically mentions a memo from John Pereira to David Marwell concerning the sensitivity of releasing information about joint US-Mexican telephone tap operations in Mexico City. This suggests Marwell held a position where he was involved in decisions regarding the declassification and release of sensitive information related to the JFK assassination. The documents span from 1993 to 1997, indicating his involvement during the ARRB's active period. The pattern across documents suggests he was a key point of contact or decision-maker within the ARRB or a related organization concerning the release of sensitive information.
key_connections: House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence (HPSCI)
significance: David Marwell's significance lies in his involvement with the ARRB and his role in decisions regarding the declassification and release of sensitive information related to the JFK assassination. He appears to have been a key figure in navigating the complexities of balancing transparency with the protection of sensitive intelligence operations and the identities of CIA employees.
